title: Discovering Goerlitz, a town in the spotlight for its link to the Grand Budapest Hotel and other movies
text:
IF ANYONE had told me a year ago I’d be sitting alone in the dust on the concrete floor of an abandoned 102-year-old department store on the German-Polish border, a building in the midst of a two-year renovation in a city I’d have struggled to find on a map just months earlier – and that I would be utterly content in doing so – well, I’d have said they were mad.
And they may well have been – if film director Wes Anderson hadn’t come to town.
I was in Goerlitz, Germany’s easternmost city, on the western banks of the Neisse River.
So far east, in fact, it has a frontier-like feel, with the Polish town of Zgorzelec a minute’s walk away over the Altstadtbrucke (Old Town Bridge). I was sitting on the ground floor of the Kaufhaus Goerlitz, a 1913 masterpiece of Historicism on the An der Frauenkirche and the building that provided the cavernous interiors for those memorable lobby scenes in Anderson’s 2014 film The Grand Budapest Hotel .
Ralph Fiennes, Bill Murray, Edward Norton, Adrien Brody, they were all right here, filming from November 2012 to March 2013. And now I was here – two years too late, sure, but no less exhilarating as lines like “Why do you want to be a Lobby Boy?” and “She’s been murdered ... and you think I did it”, faintly echoed about me. Costumed extras scurrying, clapboards snapping. “And ... action!”
Goerlitz is, by its own admission, “the most beautiful city in Germany”. I wouldn’t dare argue it. Spared the ravages of World War II, it was again left largely untouched in the decades that followed thanks to a cash-strapped East German government that couldn’t afford to do to it what it wanted to in the early 1980s – rip up its neighbourhoods of “cold, ageing buildings” with their frayed wiring and bad plumbing, and start over with smaller, functional Soviet-era apartments which, while truly ugly, were at least affordable and functional. Filmmakers love Goerlitz’s streetscapes, untouched by modernity. Source: Supplied
In the end, its 4000 historically listed buildings – from Baroque and Gothic to Historicism and Art Nouveau – survived the German Democratic Republic’s “town planners” and now represent a density of lavishly restored buildings without equal in Germany, with examples too numerous to mention.
However, what must not be missed is an antiquarian library housed in the 17th-century Barockhaus at #30 Neissstrasse, with more than 100,000 books and manuscripts dating to the Middle Ages, and next to it the Museumsleitung Archaologie, as great a museum devoted to science and archeology as I’ve ever seen. “I only wish we had more visitors”, its director, Dr Jasper von Richtofen confided. A descendant of Baron von Richtofen himself, World War I’s Red Baron no less, he laments Goerlitz’s relative isolation and the impact that has on visitor numbers. So go see it.
To better understand Goerlitz, cross the Altstadtbrucke into Zgorzelec, a suburb of Goerlitz until national boundaries were redrawn after the defeat of Nazi Germany. Sadly Zgorzelec – more tied to Goerlitz than Goerlitz is to it – has not fared well under Polish rule. Cigarettes may be cheaper there, and pizzas and vodka too, but living standards are poor and there is no mistaking the disparity in living standards one can plainly see along the eastern banks of the Neisse.
Goerlitz’s labyrinth of streets and alleyways were used to great effect by Anderson in GBH and are of themselves not an uncommon sight in Europe. What makes Goerlitz unique, though, is its vast untouched swathe of 17th, 18th and 19th-century neighbourhoods that fan out from its 15th and 16th-century cobblestoned heart.
Filmmakers love coming here because its broad avenues and streetscapes effectively double for Prague, Paris, even pre-war Berlin, yet at a fraction of the production costs. Actors love it because of the almost complete absence of meddlesome paparazzi, and a rare degree of anonymity.
During the filming of GBH, Jeff Goldblum was often seen playing piano unmolested at the restaurant Lucie Schulte. Jude Law went jogging every morning. Owen Wilson tried getting into a local punk club but wasn’t recognised and turned away. Bill Murray would walk around the corner from the Hotel Boerse to Senfladen’s for their Thuringian bratwurst sausages with mustard, gherkin, and extra spices. Wes Anderson on set of The Grand Budapest Hotel. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
Nicolas Cage loves Goerlitz so much he planned his 40th birthday here. “I drank with him till 2am”, the owner of the Hotel Boerse told me over a coffee, “then we went for a stroll through the Old Town”.
Emma Thompson is there right now filming the 1930s drama Alone in Berlin . I know this because she walked right by me. “Hi Emma” I said, and she looked at me, smiled like I was an old friend, and said hi back. That afternoon I saw her cycling through the Old Town without a care in the world.
On my last day, while struggling through a poppyseed cake in the courtyard of the Cafehaus Lucullus I met Sebastien, an extra in a kitchen scene playing a cook opposite the US actor Bob Balaban. Now he has an agent. “Because I am on their books I jumped the queue that went around the block when the call went out for extras for Alone in Berlin ”.
No wonder people are starting to call it “Goerliwood”. You can even buy the T-shirts. It seemed everyone had been caught up in the glow of the spotlights. Sitting there, covered in the dust of the Kaufhaus Goerlitz, so had I.

GETTING THERE
Lufthansa flies to Frankurt via Singapore ( lufthansa.com ). Frankfurt has daily rail services to Goerlitz via Dresden.
STAYING THERE
The Hotel Paul Otto is wonderfully situated in the Old Town.
Doubles with stucco ceilings from 105 euro. See hotelpaulotto.de
SEE AND DO
Permission is needed to visit Kaufhaus Goerlitz. For access, email info@kaufhaus-goerlitz.eu To see the Kaufhaus Goerlitz’s ongoing restoration, see kaufhaus-goerlitz.eu
